description: From un- (“de-, dis-, away”) +‎ man (“male person”). Compare Dutch ontmannen, German entmannen, both “to unman, emasculate, castrate”.

verbs.description: unman (third-person singular simple present unmans, present participle unmanning, simple past and past participle unmanned)

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To castrate; to remove the manhood of.
(transitive, figurative) To sap (a person) of the strength, whether physical or emotional, required to deal with a situation.
